raw_text:
China now top trader with Japan
 
 China overtook the US to become Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, according to numbers released by Japan's Finance Ministry on Wednesday.
 
 China accounted for 20.1% of Japan's trade in 2004, compared with 18.6% for the US. In 2003, the US was ahead with 20.5% and China came second with 19.2%. The change highlights China's growing importance as an economic powerhouse. In 2004, Japan's imports from and exports to China (and Hong Kong) added up to 22,201bn yen ($214.6bn;£114.5bn). This is the highest figure for Japanese trade with China since records began in 1947. It compares with 20,479.5bn yen in trade with the US.
 
 Trade with the US during 2004 was hurt by one-off factors, including a 13-month ban on US beef imports following the discovery of a cow infected with mad cow disease (BSE) in the US. However, economists predict China will become an even more important Japanese trading partner in the coming years. On Tuesday, figures showed China's economy grew by 9.5% in 2004 and experts say the overall growth picture remains strong. Analysts see two spurs to future growth as being China's membership of the World Trade Organisation and lower trade tariffs. During 2004, Japan's trade surplus grew 17.9% to 12.011 trillion yen, with more than half the surplus, 6.962 trillion yen, accounted for by its trade with the US. In December, the surplus grew 1.8% on a year ago to 1.14 trillion yen thanks to stronger-than-expected exports.
llama3.2:1b: China surpassed Japan as Japan's top trading partner in 2004, accounting for 20.1% of Japan's trade that year.
China's trade with Japan increased by 22.201 billion yen ($214.6 billion) to 22.201 billion yen in 2004, the highest figure since records began in 1947.
This represents an increase of over 19 billion yen from 2003, as China continues to grow in importance as a trading partner.
llama3.2:3b: China overtook the US as Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, accounting for 20.1% of Japan's trade.
China's trade with Japan increased by $214.6 billion in 2004, its highest figure since records began in 1947.
Economists predict China will become an even more important trading partner due to its growing economy and membership in the World Trade Organisation.
gemma2:2b: China is now Japan's biggest trading partner, surpassing the US in 2004.
Trade between China and Japan reached record levels in 2004, with imports from China totaling over $214 billion.
This trend is expected to continue as China's economy grows and participates in global trade organizations.
qwen2.5:0.5b: China overtook the US to become Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, surpassing it by about 3 percentage points.
The numbers show that China accounted for 20.1% of Japan's trade in 2004 compared with 18.6% for the US and 20.5% for the Japanese economy overall.
Trade between China and Japan grew from 2 billion yen (about $39 million) in 2003 to 22 trillion yen ($214.6 trillion) in 2004, highlighting China's growing importance as a trading partner.
Trade with the US also faced challenges due to BSE-related restrictions during 2004.
Analysts predict that China will become even more important in the future and expect strong growth from its membership of the World Trade Organisation and lower tariffs.
qwen2.5:1.5b: China surpassed the United States as Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, accounting for 20.1% of Japan's trade compared to 18.6% for the US.

This marks China's growing importance as an economic powerhouse and highlights changes influenced by factors such as a ban on US beef imports due to mad cow disease (BSE) and strong overall growth in the Chinese economy.
qwen2.5:3b: China surpassed the US as Japan's largest trading partner in 2004, accounting for 20.1% of Japanese trade compared to the US's 18.6%.
In 2003, the US had a larger share (20.5%) followed by China (19.2%).
By 2004, Japan’s imports and exports with China (and Hong Kong) reached 22,201bn yen ($214.6bn; £114.5bn), the highest since 1947.
This figure is above that of US trade which was 20,479.5bn yen in 2004.
The US-Japan trade relationship saw growth impacted by a 13-month ban on beef imports due to mad cow disease concerns.
Analysts predict China’s importance as Japan's trading partner will increase significantly with its WTO membership and reduced tariffs.
In 2004, Japanese trade surplus reached 12.011 trillion yen, with over half (6.962 trillion yen) attributed to US-exports.

In 2003, the US was ahead with 20.5%.
The change highlights China's growing importance as an economic powerhouse.
Japan has seen a high figure in trade with China since the start of 19th century (since records began in 1947), compared to 20,479.5bn yen in trade with the US in 2004.
However, economists predict China will become even more important in the coming years as Japan's economy grows.
During 2004, China's economy grew by 9.5% and analysts say it remains strong overall growth picture.
During 2004, Japan's trade surplus grew 17.9% to 12.011 trillion yen, with more than half of the surplus, 6.962 trillion yen, accounted for by its trade with the US.
In December, the surplus grew 1.8% on a year ago to 1.14 trillion yen thanks to stronger-than-expected exports.

It compares with 20,479.5bn yen in trade with the US.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: China has become the top trader with Japan in 2004, surpassing the US and becoming Japan's largest trading partner.
In 2004, China accounted for 20.1% of Japan's trade compared to the US' 18.6%, a significant shift from previous years where the US held the lead.
Trade figures showed Japan importing 22,201 billion yen and exporting 12,011 trillion yen in 2004, with half coming from the US—6,962 billion yen.
Despite a 13-month ban on beef imports due to BSE in the US, economists predict China will strengthen its trade relations.
The US' trade surplus grew by 17.9% to 12.011 trillion yen that year, with half from Japan to the US.
Strong export performance contributed 1.8% growth last December.
Analysts identify two factors—China's WTO membership and lower tariffs—as spurs for future growth.
tinyllama:1.1b: In 2004, China overtook the US as Japan's biggest trading partner, according to data released by Japan's Finance Ministry on Wednesday.
This change highlights China's growing importance in Japan's trade with China, which added up to 22,201 billion yen ($214.6 billion) in Japanese imports and exports to China (and Hong Kong) in 2004.

Trade with the US during that year was hurt by one-off factors, including a ban on US beef imports after BSE discoveries and a stronger dollar, but experts predict that China will become an even more important Japanese trading partner in the coming years.
Overall, Japan's trade surplus grew 17.9% to 12.011 trillion yen ($114.5 billion), with 6.962 trillion yen ($6.97 trillion) accounted for by its trade with the US.
tinydolphin:1.1b: China overtook the US to become Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, according to numbers released by Japan's Finance Ministry on Wednesday.
This shows that China has grown in importance as an economic powerhouse and continues to strengthen their relationship with Japan.
In 2004, Japan's imports from and exports to China (and Hong Kong) added up to 22,201bn yen ($214.6bn; £114.5bn).
This is the highest figure for Japanese trade with China since records began in 1947, and it compares with a 20,479.5bn yen trade with the US during 2004.

Despite the ban on US beef imports following the discovery of BSE in 2003, trade with the US increased by one-off factors like a 13-month ban on US beef imports following the detection of an infected cow.
This suggests that China could become even more important to Japan's economy in the future as they continue to grow rapidly.
According to analysts, China's economic growth in 2004 was stronger than the US's, with Japan's trade surplus growing by 17.9%.
This growth is attributed to China's increased membership of the World Trade Organisation and lower trade tariffs.

Overall, while the US had a significant impact on Japan's trading position in 2004, analysts predict that China's economy will become even more important for Japan in the coming years as it continues to grow at a strong pace.
phi:2.7b: China overtook the US as Japan's biggest trading partner in 2004, accounting for 20.1% of Japan's trade compared to 18.6% for the US.
This highlights China's growing importance as an economic powerhouse and predicts that it will become even more important in the coming years.

Japan's trade with the US was hurt by one-off factors such as a ban on US beef imports, but economists predict that China will continue to be an important trading partner due to its strong economy and membership of the World Trade Organisation.
The surplus between Japan and the US also grew strongly in 2004, with exports from the US contributing the majority of this growth.

US trade was affected by a ban on US beef imports due to mad cow disease.
Economists expect China's importance to grow, supported by its 9.5% economic growth in 2004, WTO membership, and lower trade tariffs.

In December, the surplus increased 1.8% due to strong exports.
stablelm2:1.6b: China has become Japan's biggest trading partner, overtaking the US, according to numbers released by Japan's Finance Ministry.
China accounted for 1% of Japan's trade in Q4, compared to 6% for the US.
In Q3, the US was ahead with 5% and China came second with 2%.
The growth highlights China's growing importance as an economic powerhouse.
During Q4, Japanese imports from and exports to China (and Hong Kong) added up to ¥8 trillion ($6 billion; £5 billion).
This is the highest figure for Japanese trade with China since records began in 1977.
Trade with the US during Q4 was hurt by a one-off factor, including a ban on US beef imports following the discovery of mad cow disease in the US.
Experts predict China will become an even more important Japanese trading partner in the coming years due to stronger economic growth and lower trade tariffs.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, China surpassed the US as Japan's largest trading partner, accounting for 20.1% of Japan's trade compared to the US's 18.6%.
This marked a shift from 2003, where the US held a larger share (20.5%) and China was second with 19.2%.
In 2004, Japan's total trade with both countries amounted to 22,201 billion yen ($214.6bn), the highest since records began in 1947.
Trade with the US declined due to a beef import ban, but economists anticipate China will further grow as an essential trading partner for Japan.
China's 9.5% annual growth and WTO membership, along with lower trade tariffs, are expected to drive this expansion.
During 2004, Japan's trade surplus increased by 17.9% to 12.011 trillion yen, with the majority attributed to US trade.
In December, the surplus grew 1.8% year-over-year to 1.14 trillion yen, bolstered by robust exports.
